_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

GLENDALE WASTE WATER TREATMENT PLANT

CITY OF LAKELAND 



1.    Corporate Prevention and Emergency Response Approach



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant is part of the Wastewater Operations Division of the City of Lakeland, Florida.  The City of Lakeland requires each facility to develop and maintain accident prevention programs and an emergency response plan appropriate to the site.  Each site is also responsible for regulatory compliance issues that apply to the site.  The City of Lakeland Office of Risk Management provides assistance in training for site employees and in budgeting and procurement of safety and training services.



2.    Description of Stationary Source



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant is located at 1825 Glendale Street in the Southeast corner of Lakeland, Florida.  The plant consists of disinfection, filtration, clarification, and aeration processes which treat wastewater for the City of Lakeland.



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant adds chlorine to the filtered wastewater as a disinfection agent.  The chlorination process is located in an enclosed building, that includes a scrubber capable of filtering up to one ton, located on the southwest corner of the property, where liquefied chlorine gas is stored in up to 16 one-ton containers.  Eight containers are always connected to the chlorination system with 4 online and 4 on standby.  Up to 8 one-ton containers may be stored nearby.  The total maximum chlorine inventory in the process is 32,000 lbs.  This exceeds the 2,500 lb. RMP threshold quantity.



3.    Prevention Program



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant has a program in place to comply with the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  The PSM Program was established in 1997 for the chlorine process. The program includes written operating procedures, preventative maintenance, and employee training to ensure safe operation of the chlorine process.  The PSM Program receives ful

l support of plant management and involvement of employees at all levels.



4.    Accident History



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.



5.    Emergency Response Program



The Glendale Waste Water Treatment Plant has an Emergency Response Program in place.  The program complies with 29 CFR 1910.38.  The site is developing a program to coordinate response efforts with the Lakeland Fire Department, the Polk County Hazardous Materials Response Team, and the District 7 Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Notification is made locally by dialing 911, and by notifying the Florida State Warning Point at (800) 320-0519.
